or passages of its own, with which each superficial cell communicates by
two small apertures; and that the only real external orifices, are the
minute pores at the margin of the disk, which communicate, not
directly with the cells of the superficial layers, but with the
passages of the intermediate stratum.

7. A very important addition to this limited measure of
information, was made not long afterwards by Prof. Williamson
of Manchester; who, in a Paper read before the Microscopical
Society of London, <s>12</s> June 12, 1850, and published in its Transactions
(First Series <s>I</s>, Vol III, March 1857.), first gave a minute description
of the small recent <u>Orbitolites marginalis</u> of Lamarck (which,
however, he designated as <u>O. complanata)</u>; <s>I</s> contrasted it with that
of a large recent Orbitolite from Tonga, shown by his description
to be identical with the Marginopora of Quoy & Gaimard; to
my previous account of which, he added some important
particulars; and compared both with the well known
<u>Orbiculina</u> adunca of the Bahamas. This investigation led
him to the conclusion, that these three forms, should rank under
the same genus <u>Orbiculina</u>; their most important structural
